name: Great Pyramid of Giza
shortInfo: The last surviving wonder of the ancient world.
detailedInfo:
Built around 2560 BC for Pharaoh Khufu, the Great Pyramid is the largest of the Giza pyramids and an enduring symbol of ancient Egyptian engineering.

It was originally 146.6 meters tall and made of over 2 million limestone blocks. The pyramid aligns precisely with the cardinal points and was part of a larger complex including smaller pyramids, temples, and boat pits.

Today, it remains one of the most visited tourist attractions in Egypt, symbolizing the grandeur of ancient Egyptian civilization.

name: Great Sphinx of Giza
shortInfo: Iconic limestone statue with a lion's body and human head.
detailedInfo:
Carved from a single limestone ridge, the Sphinx stands on the Giza Plateau and is believed to represent Pharaoh Khafre. It has fascinated visitors for millennia.

The Sphinx is 73 meters long and 20 meters high, carved directly from the bedrock. It has undergone many restoration efforts throughout history.

Its enigmatic expression continues to inspire myths and theories about its purpose and origins.

name: Grand Egyptian Museum (GEM)
shortInfo: The largest archaeological museum in the world, located near the pyramids.
detailedInfo:
The Grand Egyptian Museum is Egypt's newest and most advanced cultural project.

It is designed to house the world's most significant collection of ancient Egyptian artifacts.

For the first time in history, the complete Tutankhamun collection — over 5,000 pieces — will be displayed together.

The museum overlooks the Giza Pyramids and features interactive halls, advanced preservation labs, and educational centers.

Its architecture is designed to reflect the lines of the desert and the pyramids.

name: Karnak Temple
shortInfo: One of the largest temple complexes in the world.
detailedInfo:
Karnak spans a vast area with massive columns, obelisks, and chapels built over many dynasties, mainly dedicated to the god Amun-Ra.

The complex includes the Great Hypostyle Hall with 134 massive columns, some reaching 24 meters in height. It was a central place of worship for over 2,000 years.

Visitors today can witness light and sound shows that bring the history of Karnak to life.

name: Luxor Temple
shortInfo: A major ancient Egyptian temple located on the Nile's east bank.
detailedInfo:
Luxor Temple was built largely by Amenhotep III and Ramses II and served as the center of the annual Opet Festival.

Unlike many other temples, Luxor Temple was not dedicated to a god but to the rejuvenation of kingship. It was linked to Karnak Temple by the Avenue of Sphinxes.

At night, the temple is beautifully lit, offering an unforgettable view by the Nile River.

name: Valley of the Kings
shortInfo: Royal burial ground of New Kingdom pharaohs.
detailedInfo:
This valley contains tombs of notable pharaohs including Tutankhamun, with richly decorated burial chambers illustrating ancient funerary beliefs.

There are more than 60 tombs in the valley, decorated with hieroglyphs and paintings depicting the journey to the afterlife. The tomb of Tutankhamun, discovered in 1922, remains the most famous.

Visitors can explore several tombs with preserved colors and reliefs dating back thousands of years.

name: Hatshepsut Temple (Deir el-Bahari)
shortInfo: Mortuary temple of Queen Hatshepsut built into cliffs.
detailedInfo:
Known for its terraced design and dramatic setting, Hatshepsut's temple honors the female pharaoh and contains reliefs depicting her reign and divine birth.

Designed by Senenmut, the temple is built into limestone cliffs and consists of three terraces connected by ramps. It honors the only female pharaoh of the New Kingdom.

The site offers panoramic views of the desert and the Nile Valley.

name: Abu Simbel Temples
shortInfo: Massive rock temples of Ramses II relocated to save them from flooding.
detailedInfo:
Carved into the rock, the twin temples at Abu Simbel feature colossal statues and were moved brick-by-brick during the Aswan High Dam project to preserve them.

The temples were originally built in the 13th century BC to honor Ramses II and his queen Nefertari. During the 1960s, the entire site was relocated to avoid flooding from Lake Nasser.

Twice a year, sunlight illuminates the inner sanctuary, aligning with Ramses II’s statue — a marvel of ancient engineering.

name: Egyptian Museum (Cairo)
shortInfo: Houses a vast collection of ancient Egyptian artifacts.
detailedInfo:
The museum in Tahrir Square holds thousands of artifacts including treasures from Tutankhamun's tomb and extensive displays of pharaonic history.

Founded in 1902, the museum houses over 120,000 artifacts including mummies, jewelry, and monumental statues. The golden mask of Tutankhamun is its most iconic exhibit.

It remains a key destination for those studying Egypt’s ancient heritage.

name: Citadel of Saladin (Cairo Citadel)
shortInfo: A medieval Islamic fortification overlooking Cairo.
detailedInfo:
Built by Salah ad-Din in the 12th century, the Citadel contains mosques, museums, and offers panoramic views of the city.

The Citadel features the Mosque of Muhammad Ali, museums, and ancient military structures. It served as Egypt’s seat of government for nearly 700 years.

From its walls, visitors can enjoy sweeping views of Cairo.

name: Khan el-Khalili Bazaar
shortInfo: Historic marketplace famous for crafts and atmosphere.
detailedInfo:
Dating back to the Mamluk era, Khan el-Khalili is a vibrant souk offering handicrafts, spices, cafés, and a taste of traditional Cairo life.

Founded in the 14th century, this market still maintains its medieval atmosphere. You can find traditional lamps, jewelry, spices, and souvenirs.

It’s also home to the famous El-Fishawy Café, one of the oldest coffeehouses in Cairo.

name: Al-Azhar Mosque
shortInfo: One of the oldest Islamic institutions and mosques.
detailedInfo:
Founded in the 10th century, Al-Azhar serves as both a mosque and a leading center of Islamic learning.

Its architecture reflects Fatimid, Mamluk, and Ottoman influences, with multiple minarets and marble courtyards. It remains one of the most important centers of Islamic scholarship worldwide.

Students and scholars come from all over the world to study at Al-Azhar University.

name: Bibliotheca Alexandrina
shortInfo: Modern library and cultural center inspired by the ancient Library of Alexandria.
detailedInfo:
Opened in 2002, the Bibliotheca Alexandrina hosts millions of books, museums, and cultural events on the Mediterranean coast.

The building’s circular design symbolizes the rising sun of knowledge. It includes several museums, planetariums, and galleries.

It revives the spirit of the ancient library that once made Alexandria a center of learning and culture.

name: Montaza Palace & Gardens
shortInfo: Seaside palace with landscaped gardens and royal history.
detailedInfo:
Montaza was a royal summer residence with beautiful gardens and seaside views, now open for visitors and photography.

Built in the early 20th century by King Fuad I, the palace combines Turkish and Florentine architectural styles. Its gardens span over 150 acres with rare plants and palm trees.

Today, it’s a favorite spot for both locals and tourists.

name: Siwa Oasis
shortInfo: Remote oasis famous for palms, springs, and unique Berber culture.
detailedInfo:
Siwa offers salt lakes, springs, and the ancient Oracle Temple of Amun — a tranquil desert escape with rich local traditions.

It lies 750 km west of Cairo and is known for its salt lakes and ancient ruins. The Oracle Temple once welcomed Alexander the Great.

Visitors enjoy traditional mud-brick architecture and Siwan handicrafts.

name: Giftun Island
shortInfo: Popular island for snorkeling, clear waters, and beaches.
detailedInfo:
Giftun islands are protected areas with shallow reefs and abundant marine life; ideal for day trips and snorkeling adventures.

The island is surrounded by coral reefs rich in marine biodiversity. It’s a top snorkeling and diving site in the Red Sea.

Day tours include swimming, sunbathing, and exploring colorful reefs.

name: Aswan Nubian Villages & Felucca
shortInfo: Colorful Nubian villages and traditional felucca rides on the Nile.
detailedInfo:
Visitors enjoy boat trips, cultural exchanges with Nubian communities, and relaxing felucca sails at sunrise or sunset.

The brightly painted Nubian houses reflect traditional African motifs and colors. Locals welcome visitors with tea and cultural stories.

Felucca rides at sunset provide one of the most peaceful Nile experiences.

name: Coptic Cairo (Hanging Church & Old Churches)
shortInfo: Historic Christian quarter with ancient churches and museums.
detailedInfo:
Coptic Cairo includes the Hanging Church, the Coptic Museum, and centuries of Christian heritage concentrated in Old Cairo.

The Hanging Church, built above a Roman gate, dates back to the 3rd century. The Coptic Museum holds Christian manuscripts and icons.

It’s a spiritual and historical heart of Egypt’s Christian community.

name: Temple of Edfu
shortInfo: One of the best-preserved ancient temples in Egypt.
detailedInfo:
Dedicated to the falcon god Horus, the Temple of Edfu is a remarkable example of Ptolemaic architecture and features detailed hieroglyphic inscriptions.

Constructed between 237 and 57 BC, the temple celebrates the divine battle between Horus and Set. Its inscriptions provide valuable insight into Ptolemaic religion.

It remains one of the most intact temples in all of Egypt.

name: Saint Catherine's Monastery
shortInfo: Ancient Christian monastery at the foot of Mount Sinai.
detailedInfo:
Built in the 6th century, Saint Catherine's Monastery is one of the oldest working Christian monasteries and a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

Located at the foot of Mount Sinai, it houses ancient manuscripts and the Burning Bush. The monastery is sacred to Christianity, Islam, and Judaism alike.

Its remote desert setting makes it a place of peace and reflection.

name: Ras El Bar
shortInfo: Coastal resort town where the Nile meets the Mediterranean Sea.
detailedInfo:
Ras El Bar is famous for its unique location at the Nile Delta’s tip, offering sandy beaches, sea views, and local seafood.

The city was one of Egypt’s first modern resorts, popular since the early 1900s. It’s famous for its summer villas and fresh seafood.

Visitors can watch the meeting point of the Nile and the Mediterranean Sea.

name: Qaitbay Citadel
shortInfo: 15th-century fortress built on the site of the ancient Lighthouse of Alexandria.
detailedInfo:
The Qaitbay Citadel stands as a historical fort protecting Alexandria’s harbor and offering beautiful views of the Mediterranean.

Built by Sultan Al-Ashraf Qaitbay in 1477 AD using stones from the fallen Lighthouse of Alexandria. It protected the city against Ottoman invasions.

Today, it stands as a landmark of Alexandria’s maritime heritage.

name: Philae Temple
shortInfo: Ancient temple dedicated to the goddess Isis, relocated after High Dam construction.
detailedInfo:
Philae Temple is considered one of the most beautiful temples in Egypt.

Originally located on Philae Island, the temple was threatened by rising waters after the construction of the Aswan High Dam.

In a historic rescue mission led by UNESCO, the entire complex was dismantled and moved to Agilkia Island block by block.

The temple is dedicated to Isis, the goddess of magic and motherhood, and features impressive pylons, sanctuaries, and detailed reliefs that depict ancient myths and royal rituals.

Today, the island setting and evening Sound & Light show make Philae one of Aswan’s top attractions.

name: Temple of Kom Ombo
shortInfo: Unique double temple dedicated to Sobek and Horus.
detailedInfo:
The Temple of Kom Ombo is unique in Egypt because it is dedicated to two gods simultaneously.

One half honors Sobek, the crocodile god and symbol of fertility, while the other half honors Horus the Elder, the falcon god.

Its symmetrical layout reflects this dual worship and creates a distinctive architectural style.

Nearby excavations uncovered mummified crocodiles, now displayed in the Crocodile Museum.

Inside the temple, detailed reliefs show ancient medical tools, making Kom Ombo one of the earliest historical references to surgery and medicine.

name: Dendera Temple
shortInfo: Well-preserved temple complex dedicated to Hathor.
detailedInfo:
The Dendera Temple complex is one of Egypt’s best-preserved ancient sites.

Its main structure, the Temple of Hathor, features vibrant colors, decorated ceilings, and massive columns.

The temple is famous for the Dendera Zodiac, an ancient astronomical carving.

It also contains underground crypts, rooftop chapels, and reliefs depicting Cleopatra VII and her son Caesarion.

The vibrant blue ceiling paintings make it one of the most visually stunning temples in Egypt.

name: Saqqara Step Pyramid
shortInfo: Oldest pyramid in Egypt, built for King Djoser.
detailedInfo:
The Step Pyramid of Djoser is the oldest large-scale stone structure in the world.

Designed by the architect Imhotep, it marked a revolutionary leap in ancient Egyptian architecture.

Its step design represents the early evolution of pyramid building.

Saqqara also includes tombs, temples, and ancient burial chambers with colorful reliefs.

The site's vast landscape makes it a key stop for understanding Egypt’s early dynasties.

name: Dahshur (Bent & Red Pyramids)
shortInfo: Two unique pyramids showing evolution of pyramid building.
detailedInfo:
Dahshur is home to two remarkable pyramids built by Pharaoh Sneferu.

The Bent Pyramid is famous for its unusual change in angle halfway up, revealing early architectural experimentation.

The Red Pyramid is considered the world’s first true smooth-sided pyramid.

Both structures demonstrate the evolution of pyramid design before the Great Pyramid of Giza.

Dahshur is quieter and less crowded, offering an authentic desert experience.

name: El-Moez Street
shortInfo: Historic Islamic street filled with mosques, palaces, and old markets.
detailedInfo:
El-Moez Street is one of the oldest and most significant streets in Islamic Cairo.

It features well-preserved Mamluk and Fatimid architecture, including mosques, palaces, and traditional houses.

The street is a living outdoor museum reflecting over 1,000 years of Islamic art.

Its vibrant atmosphere includes markets, coffee shops, and cultural performances.

At night, the area is beautifully illuminated, making it a favorite spot for tourists and photographers.

name: Baron Empain Palace
shortInfo: Unique Indian-inspired palace built in the early 1900s.
detailedInfo:
The Baron Empain Palace is one of Cairo’s most unusual architectural landmarks.

Built by Belgian industrialist Édouard Empain, the palace’s design was inspired by Hindu temples and Cambodian architecture.

Its rotating tower was originally designed to turn for sunlight.

After years of abandonment, the palace was restored and reopened, showcasing exhibitions about Heliopolis and the life of Baron Empain.

The building is also surrounded by popular legends and supernatural stories.

name: Fayoum – Wadi El Hitan (Valley of the Whales)
shortInfo: UNESCO site with prehistoric whale fossils.
detailedInfo:
Wadi El Hitan is a UNESCO World Heritage Site famous for its prehistoric whale fossils.

The fossils belong to early whales that still had legs, documenting a critical stage in evolution.

The site includes open-air walking trails and a modern visitor center.

Its desert scenery and scientific importance make it one of Egypt’s most unique attractions.

name: Port Said Lighthouse
shortInfo: Historic lighthouse marking the entrance of the Suez Canal.
detailedInfo:
The Port Said Lighthouse was built in 1869 to guide ships entering the Suez Canal.

It is one of the earliest structures made of reinforced concrete.

The lighthouse represents the birth of Port Said as a major international port.

Its historical significance and unique architecture make it a notable landmark.

name: Al-Alamein War Museum
shortInfo: Museum commemorating WWII battles in North Africa.
detailedInfo:
The Al-Alamein War Museum recounts the major battles of World War II that took place along Egypt’s northern coast.

It includes uniforms, weapons, vehicles, letters, and military maps.

Outdoor exhibits feature tanks, artillery, and remnants of war.

The museum honors soldiers from various nations who fought in the desert campaigns.

name: Mount Sinai (Jebel Musa)
shortInfo: Sacred mountain traditionally believed to be where Moses received the Ten Commandments.
detailedInfo:
Mount Sinai is one of the most sacred sites in the world.

Pilgrims and travelers climb the mountain at night to witness the sunrise from the summit.

The route passes monasteries, chapels, and ancient stone steps.

From the top, the surrounding mountains of Sinai create a breathtaking view.

The site holds spiritual significance for Christianity, Islam, and Judaism.

name: Abdeen Palace
shortInfo: Royal palace from the Muhammad Ali dynasty.
detailedInfo:
Abdeen Palace served as the official residence of Egypt’s royal family.

It contains lavish halls, military museums, and collections of royal artifacts.

name: Manial Palace
shortInfo: A palace blending Islamic, Ottoman, and European styles.
detailedInfo:
Built by Prince Mohamed Ali Tawfik, the palace features rare art, manuscripts, and beautifully decorated rooms.

The surrounding gardens add to its elegance.
